rows.title: Tax advantage for domestic businesses over foreign-based exporters and investors in Canada
rows.summary:
This affects UK businesses with operations in Canada. A private corporation which is controlled by Canadian residents may be designated a Canadian Controlled Private Corporation (CCPC). These are eligible for various tax advantages such as small business deductions on income tax, enhanced investment tax credits and shareholder entitlement to capital gains exemption.
 
This means that CCPC net tax rate is 9% compared to 15% for other corporations. As a result, UK companies with operations in Canada face added costs.

rows.title: Difficulties accessing French Olympic procurement opportunities
rows.summary:
UK businesses trying to bid for contracts for the Paris 2024 Olympics are facing a number of challenges:
(i) Lack of transparency about procurement opportunities. 
(ii) Information is not consistently available even when it is publicised. 
(iii) Smaller offers - falling below the price ceiling set by the French Olympic Committee - are not publicised, and so UK companies wanting to offer their services as subcontractors do not have the necessary information about which company won which contract.
(iv) Businesses bidding need to enter a French phone number into the platform in order to proceed with their bids.

rows.title: Federal and provincial measures affecting beverage alcohol exports to Canada
rows.summary:
Liquor boards in Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia and Nova Scotia have practices that appear discriminatory, hindering UK beverage alcohol access. These practices include distribution, licensing and sales measures such as product mark-ups, market access, listing policies, and duties and taxes applied federally and provincially. 
Through consultations, Canada will repeal the federal excise tax exemption on Canadian made wine; Nova Scotia will terminate price supports for locally made wines; and Ontario has eliminated tax differences between Ontario and non-Ontario wines and removed beer and wine authorisation restrictions.

Active measures:
In BC, small firms bypass cost of service fees by producing below a threshold, giving domestic suppliers an advantage, as they are generally smaller than firms exporting. Beverage alcohol exporters face total mark-ups of 223-225%, with 258-260% for spirits in BC.
In Ontario, domestic ready-to-drink beverages are given preferential treatment.

rows.title: Different classifications of blood products affecting access to Export Heath Certificates for UK black pudding producers
rows.summary:
This affects UK black pudding producers exporting to Canada. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) classifies black pudding or blood sausage as a meat product. The UK Animal Plant Health Agency does not. This means that black pudding exporters cannot access export health certificates (EHCs) for export to Canada.

UK black pudding producers cannot use EHC 7068 as this certificate is for meat products only.

EHC 6671 covering blood products is not designed for blood products for human consumption and therefore cannot be used to export black pudding.

This classification issue prevents the export of black pudding from the UK to Canada.

rows.title: Vodka Classification restricted certain beverage alcohol products to be labelled as Vodka in Canada
rows.summary:
Prior to 2019, vodka sold in Canada could only be labelled as such if it were made with potato or grain. This excluded the UK companies who make vodka with cow's milk and with grapes from labelling their product as 'vodka'. This negatively impacted their ability to communicate what their product was to consumers. These products also were not allowed to be placed in the same section as the other vodka products.

Following consultation, the Food and Drug Regulations were amended to state:
 
“Vodka shall be a potable alcoholic distillate obtained from potatoes, cereal grain or any other material of agricultural origin fermented by the action of yeast or a mixture of yeast and other micro-organisms.

Vodka produced, in whole or in part, from material of agricultural origin other than potatoes or cereal grain, shall carry in close proximity to the common name, the statement “produced from” followed by the name of all material of agricultural origin used”.

rows.title: UK and EU's method for collecting edible blood is not accepted by the CFIA in Canada
rows.summary:
CFIA (the Canadian Food Inspection Agency) requires edible blood, edible blood fractions (eg plasma, clotting factors, cells) and edible meat products containing blood and/or blood fractions (eg sausages, blood pudding) derived from bovines or swine slaughtered in the EU, to be certified as using a closed blood collection method eg using a hollow knife, or cannula.  

This export requirement means that these blood products, often produced with alternative methods, cannot be exported to Canada.

rows.title: Packaging and labelling requirements for alcoholic drinks affect UK exports to Canada
rows.summary:
The Safe Food for Canada Regulations (SFCR) has strict rules on packaging. Consumer prepackaged bottled wine may only be traded between provinces or imported to Canada in a container with a size corresponding to a net quantity by volume of 50, 100, 200, 250, 375, 500 or 750 millimetres or 1, 1.5, 2, 3 or 4 litres. This only applies to sale to, or by, a duty-free shop or free samples.

The Liquor Control Board of Ontario (LCBO) will not retail alcohol products that may appeal to persons under the legal drinking age due to their Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) mandate. This includes using adverts with certain cartoons and these decisions can have the potential to use subjective interpretation.

rows.title: Short deadlines affecting UK companies bidding for infrastructure contracts in Canada
rows.summary: This affects UK companies bidding for contracts in Canada. Procurement requests for proposals (RFPs) are increasingly being released with short deadlines. This makes it harder for bidders to explore ventures and partnerships, secure resources and review the large amounts of information in time.

rows.title: Fortifications required for simulated meat products exported to Canada
rows.summary:
The following products require fortifications and amino acids to be added to be exported and sold in Canada: simulated meat products, simulated poultry meat products, meat product extenders and poultry product extenders.
 
Mandatory: thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, d-pantothenic acid, folic acid, vitamin B12, iron, magnesium, potassium, zinc, copper.

Amino Acids: histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, valine.

rows.title: French language requirements for the Toubon Law affecting UK exporters/investors
rows.summary: The Toubon law in France requires labelling and information in French.  This can mean that computer software developed outside France, may need to have its interface and instruction manuals translated into French, so that it can be used in France.   An overseas business can be sued or penalised, if they do not provide their employees with French language Information Communication Technology (ICT) equipment.

rows.title: Ban on selling spirits (alcoholic drinks) in take-out and delivery orders in Quebec affecting exporters/investors
rows.summary: Spirits (alcoholic drinks) are not allowed to be sold in take-out and delivery orders in Quebec, Canada. This includes small bottles, large bottles or cocktail form. All other alcohol categories - beer, wine and cider - can be sold in takeout and delivery orders in Quebec.  All other Canadian provinces allow the sale of spirits, in some form with the exception of the Yukon and Nunavut territories which the regulations are unknown.

rows.title: Safe Food for Canadians Regulations (SFCR) affecting UK exports of food products to Canada
rows.summary:
This affects exporters of food products from the UK to Canada. Safe Food for Canadians Regulations (SFCR) came into force on 15 January 2019. These require all food products imported into Canada to go through a licensed Canadian importer. 

This adds exports costs for UK firms, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and e-commerce sellers, as they are required to hire third party facilitators.
